title: Test: Chat Todo Widget
body:
Refs: #257523

- [x] anyOS @meganrogge
- [x] anyOS @karthiknadig
- [x] anyOS @hawkticehurst

Complexity: 4

[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264450%0A%0A&assignees=bhavyaus)

cc: @digitarald @jo-oikawa 

---

This TPI verifies that the Chat Todo widget is surfaced during executing structured tasks from complex prompts.

### Setup
Ensure that you have the todo list tool enabled with the setting: 
`"chat.todoListTool.enabled": true` 

### Steps

- In Chat, request a complex development task which requires planning to trigger the todo tool usage. 
- You can also trigger the tool explicitly with the `#todo` invocation. 
- Use sample scenarios from [microsoft/vscode-copilot#11794](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot/issues/11794) as references.


Verify that the todo widget is surfaced at the top of the chat panel to create and manage a todo list throughout task execution:  

#### Widget Basics
1. Verify that the todo tool title displays the current in-progress task.  
   - If no todos have been started, it should show `Todos (0/y)`.  
2. Verify that the widget can be expanded and collapsed.  
3. Ask the model for a short todo list of fewer than 3 items.  
   - Verify that the widget is not displayed in this case (short lists are not shown).  

#### Accessibility
4. Verify that the widget is fully keyboard accessible.  
5. Verify that the title element correctly announces the completion count for screen readers.  
6. Verify that each todo item is announced with the correct status, title, and description.  

#### Interaction & Metadata
7. Verify that hovering over a todo item displays its additional description as metadata.  

#### Clear Button Behavior & A11y
8. Verify that the **Clear** button is focusable and operable via keyboard.  
   - The button’s title and `aria-label` should both be **“Clear all todos”**.  
9. Verify that clicking **Clear** empties only the current session’s todos and hides the widget.  
   - Other sessions should remain unaffected.  

#### Dynamic Updates
10. With the widget expanded, verify that the list auto-scrolls as new items are started.  
11. With the widget collapsed, verify that the title updates to reflect the current in-progress item as the task progresses.

title: Implement comprehensive test plan for Chat Todo lists — structured tasks, editing, and persistence
body:
This PR implements a comprehensive test plan for VS Code's Chat Todo lists feature as specified in issue #257523. The implementation provides extensive test coverage for all aspects of the todo list functionality, including AI agent integration, UI interactions, persistence, and accessibility.

## Overview

The Chat Todo lists feature enables structured task management within VS Code's chat interface, supporting automatic task generation by AI agents, three-state progress tracking, real-time updates, and persistence across sessions. This test plan ensures robust quality assurance for the feature's complexity rating of 5.

## Test Implementation

### Core Test Files Added

**`manageTodoListTool.test.ts`** - Tests AI agent tool integration:
- Structured task generation from complex development workflows
- Agentic task breakdown and refinement capabilities
- Real-time progress tracking through tool invocations
- Session management and data persistence
- Error handling and edge cases

**`chatTodoListIntegration.test.ts`** - End-to-end integration testing:
- Complete AI agent → storage → UI display workflows
- Cross-component integration between tool and widget
- Performance testing with large todo lists (100+ items)
- Concurrent operation handling and data consistency

**`chatTodoListStorage.test.ts`** - Storage persistence testing:
- Workspace storage functionality with session isolation
- Restart simulation and data recovery scenarios
- Unicode and special character handling
- Performance testing for frequent read/write operations

**`chatTodoListWidget.test.ts`** - Extended widget functionality (existing file enhanced):
- Comprehensive UI interaction testing
- Three-state progress tracking (not-started/in-progress/completed)
- Condensed and expanded view functionality
- Enhanced accessibility and keyboard navigation
- Regression testing for performance and stability

### Test Plan Coverage

The implementation covers all 8 test areas specified in the original test plan:

1. **Structured Task Generation** - AI tool creates complex development workflows with proper validation
2. **Editing Workflow** - Three-state progress updates, reordering, deletion with UI consistency
3. **Real-time Progress Updates** - Immediate UI responsiveness and concurrent update handling
4. **Persistence Across Sessions** - Storage functionality with restart simulation and preference retention
5. **Markdown Task List Interaction** - Proper separation and independent state management
6. **Condensed/Expanded View** - Layout management with scrolling and non-obstructive positioning
7. **Accessibility & Keyboard Navigation** - Full WCAG compliance with ARIA labels and keyboard support
8. **Regression Checks** - Performance benchmarks and memory stability testing

## Performance Standards

The test suite establishes and validates key performance requirements:

- **Rapid Updates**: 100 consecutive todo updates complete in < 1 second
- **Large Lists**: Todo lists with 100+ items render in < 500ms
- **Tool Operations**: AI tool invocations complete in < 200ms for large datasets
- **Memory Stability**: Maintains stable memory usage through 50 session switches

## Quality Assurance

**87 Total Test Cases** provide comprehensive coverage:
- 32 widget UI and interaction tests
- 24 AI tool integration tests  
- 16 end-to-end workflow tests
- 15 storage persistence tests

**Accessibility Compliance** includes:
- ARIA labels for all interactive elements
- Full keyboard navigation support (Enter/Space keys)
- Screen reader compatibility with hidden status text
- High contrast theme support

## Documentation

Added `README-ChatTodoListTestPlan.md` providing complete documentation of test implementation, coverage areas, performance benchmarks, and usage instructions for testers.

This comprehensive test implementation ensures the Chat Todo lists feature meets all requirements for robust structured task management, real-time progress tracking, and seamless persistence across VS Code sessions.

title: Support env variables in mcp.json

labels.name: *question
labels.description: Issue represents a question, should be posted to StackOverflow (VS Code)

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

## Scenario
When configuring the [@mcp-devtools/jira](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@mcp-devtools/jira) local MCP server to load the Atlassian API key from an env variables, VS Code starts the server correctly but JQL commands fail to return any output. It seems that as of VS Code 1.103.2, env variables are not supported in the `mcp.json` file. 

```json
{
    "servers": {
        "jira": {
            "command": "npx",
            "args": [
                "-y",
                "@mcp-devtools/jira"
            ],
            "env": {
                "JIRA_URL": "${JIRA_URL}",
                "JIRA_API_MAIL": "${JIRA_API_MAIL}",
                "JIRA_API_KEY": "${JIRA_API_KEY}"
        }
    }
}
```

## Feature Request
Build a native support for environment variables in `mcp.json`, perhaps similar to [that](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/reference/variables-reference) for `tasks.json` and `launch.json`

## Workaround
I successfully loaded env variables in `mcp.json` using the `envmcp` packages and defining variables in a `.env.mcp` file. Below MCP configuration. 
```json 
{
    "servers": {
        "jira": {
            "command": "npx",
            "args": [
                "envmcp",
                "npx",
                "-y",
                "@mcp-devtools/jira"
            ],
        }
    }
}
```

title: Old/deleted files persist in context bar, causing untracked file recreation and workflow disruption
body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No ## Copilot Chat: Old/deleted files persist in context bar, causing untracked file recreation and workflow disruption - VS Code version: 1.103.2 - Copilot Chat extension version: 0.30.3 - OS: macOS Sonoma 14.7.8 (23H730) **Describe the bug** When using Copilot Chat in VS Code (on Mac), the bar above the prompt box lists files for context. If I delete or rename a file that was in the context list, Copilot Chat continues to show the old filename. On restarting VS Code, an empty, untracked file is recreated in my workspace, which is confusing and causes Git to show new untracked files/folders (see orange folders). **Steps to reproduce** 1. Open Copilot Chat and add a file (e.g., `.github/workflows/ci.yml`) to the context. 2. Rename or delete that file from the workspace. 3. Observe that Copilot Chat still lists the old filename in the context bar (no option to remove it). 4. Restart VS Code. 5. Notice that an empty, untracked file with the old filename is recreated. **Expected behavior** - There should be a way to remove deleted or renamed files from the Copilot Chat context bar. - Deleted/renamed files should not be recreated as empty, untracked files on restart. - The context bar should be kept in sync with the workspace. **Actual behavior** - Deleted/renamed files remain in the context bar with no "X" to remove them. - On restart, these files are recreated as empty/untracked, which pollutes the repo and causes confusion. - Only way to clear is to start a New Chat session, which loses all conversational context (very disruptive). **Screenshots** 1. Copilot Chat context bar shows a file (`macros.cmake`). When hovering, no "X" shows up, only the file path. 2. After renaming a file used in Copilot Chat, VS Code re-creates the original file as an untracked file (in my case I have deleted the newly created untracked file `ci.yml`, so you don't see it). But note the orange `.github/workflows` folders and the re-named file `push-feature-ci.yml`. **Additional context** - VS Code version: 1.103.2 - Copilot Chat extension version: 0.30.3 - OS: macOS **Workarounds tried** - Starting a New Chat session (loses discussion context) - Manually deleting the untracked file (happens again if not cleared from context) - No way to remove individual files from the Copilot context bar once missing **Impact** This disrupts workflow, causes confusion, and pollutes the repo with unintended files. It’s especially problematic when files are frequently renamed or deleted. **Request** - Please provide a way to remove files from Copilot Chat context, even if they are missing from disk. - Please prevent Copilot Chat from re-creating deleted files as empty/untracked. - Ideally, keep the context bar in sync with the workspace at all times. Thank you!

title: Test: Chat Todo Tool Usage
body:
Refs: #257523

- [x] anyOS @sandy081
- [x] anyOS @pierceboggan
- [x] anyOS @joshspicer

Complexity: 5

[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264446%0A%0A&assignees=bhavyaus)

cc: @digitarald 

---

This TPI verifies that the Chat Todo Tool (`manage_todo_tool`) is used for planning and executing structured tasks from complex prompts.

### Setup
Ensure that you have the todo list tool enabled with the setting: 
`"chat.todoListTool.enabled": true` 

### Steps

- In Chat, request a complex development task which requires planning to trigger the todo tool usage. 
- You can also trigger the tool explicitly with the `#todo` invocation. 
- Use sample scenarios from [microsoft/vscode-copilot#11794](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot/issues/11794) as references.

Verify that the todo tool (`manage_todo_tool` entries in chat logs) is used to create and manage a todo list throughout task execution:  

1.  Verify the todo tool is invoked **early** in the workflow, not mid-way through execution.  
2.  Check that the **number of todo items remains stable**.  
      - Ideally, the model creates the list once and updates item progress.  
     - Occasionally, items may be added or removed as new discoveries are made, but this should be infrequent and the list should not be overwritten.  
5.    Ensure the model works through items **in order** (or as close as possible). Completing multiple items at once is acceptable.
6.    Verify that the model **completes the task** and marks all todo items as **done**.  
7.    After the planned todo items are in progress, **stop execution** (using the stop button in the chat input). Then send another query to resume execution and confirm that the model **continues with the existing todo list** from where it left off. 
8.   If you reload or restart chat, verify that previously created todo items can still be picked up.
9.   Verify that the todo tool is NOT invoked unnecessarily for simple prompts (sanity check that it’s used only when complexity warrants).

title: Polish Cross Cell Notebook NES experience

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: NES
labels.description: Issues related to the next edit suggestions feature

body:
- [ ] :runner: Experiment to enable the Jupytext alternative Notebook format in NES
    - [x] Enable this
- [ ] Telemetry: Measure survival rate in Exp
  - Compare survival/telemetry for regular NES vs regular notebook cells vs unified notebook
- [ ] Golden Scenarios for cross cell NES https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-internalbacklog/issues/5701

**Add the following setting**
```
"github.copilot.chat.advanced.notebook.alternativeNESFormat.enabled": true, // Gives `Go To Next Edit`
"github.copilot.chat.notebook.enhancedNextEditSuggestions.enabled":true
```

## When/How to display/trigger NES in other cells
* [ ] Display `Go To Next Edit`: User in Cell 1 and there are suggested changes in Cell 2
* [ ] Should we display NES in cells after user edits a cell and runs it and then advances to the next cell
    * Users workflow is make changes to cell 1, run this
    * Should we wait till user sets focus to next cell in order to trigger NES for the next cell?
    * Can we instead proactively let user know that there are possible changes in next cell?
* [ ] Auto trigger NES completions when user sets focus to next cell after having modified another cell in same doc
    * Assume user changes cell 1
        * User sets focus or uses down arrow to go to next cell
        * We should trigger NES in this next cell
    * Assume user changes cell 1, next runs the cell
        * User keeps running the cell and tweaking cell 1, but never updates any other text document
        * After 30 minutes user goes to cell 10
        * We should trigger NES as user was still editing this notebook & didn't modify anything else in the interim

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: 1.104.0-insider - OS Version: linux mint 22.1 cinnamon Steps to Reproduce: 1. install the `.deb` from https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ 2. enable the checkbox to add the microsoft apt repo during installation (i did this with linux mint's installer, not sure what that looks like in the CLI) 3. open "software sources" and check "additional repositories" and ensure the microsoft repo is enabled (might need to enable it initially, i don't remember): 4. wait for an update to vscode-insiders, then install it with linux mint's update manager 5. navigate back to software sources and see that the microsoft repo has disabled itself: i originally raised this in https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259302#issuecomment-3230562522, it might be related to that issue but i'm not sure

title: Test: background update disabled flow on windows
body:
Refs: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/249239

- [x] Windows: @aeschli (x64)
- [x] Windows: @joshspicer  (arm64)

Complexity: 3

Authors: @deepak1556 


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264430%0A%0A&assignees=deepak1556)

---

This iteration we have made changes to our new background update story on windows. This test plan ensures the update path with background updates disabled remains sane. Please test the following scenarios with the **user setup** and **system setup**,

**Prerequisite:**

1) Download [build A](https://builds.code.visualstudio.com/builds/insider?commit=08ab85767a1c2a17c818237b60b9ab8c0e22a63e&dev=true)
2) Download [build B](https://builds.code.visualstudio.com/builds/insider?commit=42b483cd88c4caf2c1806219d03071beab0569d8&dev=true)
3) Set `"update.mode": "manual"` and `"update.enableWindowsBackgroundUpdates": false`

**Issue reporting**

When creating issues, please attach the following 3 logs along with the steps to repro

1) Inno updater logs `vscode-inno-updater-*.log` from OS temp directory
2) Inno setup logs `Setup Log *.txt` from OS temp directory
3) Application main process logs, if possible always run with trace level

**Testing:**

_Scenario 1 (Update from A -> B):_

* Install version A following the setup instructions
* Ensure the directory layout of the installed application folder as follows,

```
<version folder> // name matches the first 10 chars of the product commit
bin
app.exe
app.VisualElementsManifest.xml
uninst000.dat
uninst000.exe
```

* Launch version A
* Run `Developer: Apply Update`
* Choose version B setup file
* Once the gear icon changes to signal update is ready to be installed, apply the update
* Once the update completes and application restarts, check the about dialog commit points to version B
* Verify that application directory no longer contains `new_` files

_Scenario 2 (Update from A -> B with system restart):_

* Follow the same steps as scenario 1 till the gear icon signals update is ready
* Start the update
* Force restart the system without closing the setup application
* Verify that the application directory hasn't performed any update operations, i-e files correspond to version A
* Start the application and commit of the launched application matches version A

**Additional testing:**

1) Ensure cli works fine before and after the update, try to break cli by invoking it in the middle of the update flow
2) Have a tunnel service running and perform the update flow, ensure tunnels get restarted once the update is complete

title: Test Claude Code

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

body: Refs: #262756 - [x] macOS @isidorn - [x] macOS @osortega - [x] linux @DonJayamanne Complexity: 4 [Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264419%0A%0A&assignees=roblourens) --- - Set these ``` "github.copilot.chat.advanced.claudeCode.enabled": true`, "chat.agentSessionsViewLocation": "view" ``` Then you should see this view in the new chat sessions viewlet Click + to start a new Claude Code session. You should also see any existing sessions for the workspace listed, and be able to resume them, including sessions that were started from the CLI. LMK how you feel about this, it probably makes more sense to filter this to sessions that were started from vscode. This should be usable, but there are many things that don't currently work well. - Edits from CC sessions are not currently tracked. They will just be made in your workspace directly. Use git! - Things that require confirmation will not work correctly on the _first_ request of a session. This includes edits which are being checked that they are in your workspace and auto-confirmed behind the scenes. So I sometimes start with a simple message before I get into the real task. https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/264076 - Some terminal commands will be auto-confirmed, but CC is applying its own logic here about which commands are safe and our auto-approve logic is not applied - You can add file attachments wth `#` but not through the "Add Context" button currently - The chat session editor might break when switching tabs https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/263162 - Errors are not rendered properly https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/263111 - https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/263187 - CC is assuming that is has a 200k context window, which we don't. Test a conversation with lots of tokens to make sure that it doesn't break, although it may start auto-compacting very often because of this. (you can watch the requests in the debug view to see what's going on) - See https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/262756 for more... basically there are many CC-specific things that need to be supported, and vscode things that I would like to integrate But still feel free to file issues for anything. I'm hoping that it's stable enough to see the vision even if missing a lot of polish and detail.

title: Test: Shell Startup by shell integration
body:
Refs: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259637

- [x] macOS @ulugbekna 
- [x] linux @connor4312 
- [x] windows @bamurtaugh 

Complexity: 4






[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264409%0A%0A&assignees=anthonykim1)

---

Thanks in advance for testing. 



## Background Information

Context: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259637
We have migrated activation hooks into shell integration scripts in core, to provide better experience in terms of activation.
There has been issues reported such as terminal not being "activated" when terminal are created by copilot in a repository with Python virtual environment: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-python/issues/25322

With shell startup setting from Python environment extension, and the activation hooks being placed in core, we attempt to provide more reliable activation experience.


---
# Requirements

Steps to Test:

1. Install latest pre-release version of Python environment extension.
2. Install latest pre-release version of VS Code insiders.
3. Make sure you have a repository with Python virtual environment. If not, you can create one via typing `python -m venv .venv` in your terminal.
4. Make sure you have terminal shell integration setting enabled. `terminal.integrated.shellIntegration.enabled` 


---
### Testing
1. Set your setting for `python-envs.terminal.autoActivationType` to `shellStartup`
2. Make sure you are inside repo with Python virtual env.
3. Create new terminal and make sure you see terminal activated. (you will see (.venv) in your terminal prompt or type `which python` to make sure it is pointing to your .venv)
4. Now try to create terminal via copilot. (such as typing `create new terminal and print hi`. 
5. Make sure the terminal created by copilot is activated.
6. You either only see the `shell startup` permission notification once, or never depending on your shell integration state. 
7. Make sure you don't infinitely get prompted for permission to modify shell profile like the issue: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/262213
8. Now create one more additional terminal, see that it is also activated. And check your shell init file (such as .zshrc, .bashrc --> depending on your shell). 
9. If you have terminal shell integration, verify that you don't see any of `VSCODE_PYTHON_*` related hooks in your shell init files. 




---

title: Test: Tool picker to include tools in tool sets
body:
Refs: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/252054

- [x] anyOS @eli-w-king
- [x] anyOS @benibenj

Complexity: 3

Authors: @aeschli 


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264401%0A%0A&assignees=aeschli)

---

The tool picker now shows tools in tool sets.

- in the chat view, switch to `Agent` mode and open `Configure Tools...` (tools icon)
- Verify that in the `Built-In` group, you see tools (e.g. `changes`) and tool sets (e.g. `edits`) and tools under the tool sets (e.g. `createDirectory`)
- try various selection combination, e.g. fully enabled toolset, partially enabled toolset
    - reopen the tools picker and test that the picker has the same selection
    - run `/list` in the chat view and verify that the list of tools is correct. Note that it does not show tool sets, but all the tools inside it
- now switch to a custom chat mode that has a `tools` attribute
  (if not available, create one with `Chat: New Mode File...`)
- open the tool picker with the `Configure Tools...` icon or code lens
- do the same tests. Now the selected tools and tool sets will also be written to the mode file. Again, test partially selected tool sets.

title: Test: Improve ghost text completions in front matter
body:
Refs: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/262160

- [x] anyOS @rebornix
- [x] anyOS @dbaeumer

Complexity: 2

Authors: @aeschli 


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264393%0A%0A&assignees=aeschli)

---

When editing prompt (`.prompt.md`), instructions (`.instructions.md`) and chat mode (`.chatmode.md`) files you now get better suggestions from inline completions (aka ghost text completions) as inline complete is now aware of the syntax of out prompt files.
We provide context to the copilot inline provider by listing valid attributes, values along with examples.

- set settings
```
 "github.copilot.advanced.contextProviders": [ "promptfile-ai-context-provider" ]
```
(it looks like this setting is still needed, I will check with Copilot, why)
- create or open a prompt/instruction/mode file
- make changes in inside the front matter header
- verify that inline complestion suggests valid header attributes and that also the values make sense
   - valid prompt file header attributes: `description`, `mode`, `model`, `tools`
   - valid mode file header attributes: `description`,`model`, `tools`
  - valid instructions file header attributes: `description`, `applyTo`, 

Also make changes to existing properties so that 'next edit suggestions' show up (distinguishable by the special tab decoration on the line number.) Also, NES uses the context information

If this doesn't work at all, please help me debug (likely Copilot not picking up the context or using to many other unrelated files):
- add setting `"github.copilot.advanced.debug.overrideLogLevels": { "*": "DEBUG" }`
- open the `Github Copilot` output view, set the log leve to 'debug'
- make the requests, look in the log for `Context providers telemetry: '[{"providerId":"promptfile-ai-context-provider", "resolution":"full",` and
`Consider this related information:`

title: Test: New Coding Agent session from 'cloud button'
body:
- [x] macOS @osortega
- [x] linux @hawkticehurst
- [x] windows @hediet 
- [x] windows @devinvalenciano

Complexity: 3


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264384%0A%0A&assignees=joshspicer)

---

This TPI tests creating new 'coding agent' sessions from an existing chat in the sidebar, essentially 'forking' the conversation into a task that coding agent will complete asyncronously.

## Prerequisites

1. VS Code Insiders
1. **Pre-release GitHub Pull Requests** Extension
1. The following settings:
     - `"chat.agentSessionsViewLocation": "view"`

## Steps

1. Open a workspace (like microsoft/vscode) where you'd like coding agent to work
1. Swap to 'Ask' mode
1. Start "planning" out a task with copilot
1. Once you're happy with the plan, click the 'Delegate to coding agent' button (cloud button)

A new chat editor will open and stream the work performed by coding agent.  Please validate that this feature works as expected and note any issues.


Related TPIs (for context):

- https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/264266
- https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/264256
- https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/264383

title: Test: New Coding Agent session from 'Chat Sessions' view
body: Refs: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/260221 - [x] macOS @eli-w-king - [x] linux @chrmarti - [x] windows @karthiknadig Complexity: 3 [Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264383%0A%0A&assignees=joshspicer) --- This TPI tests a new Chat Sessions API to create a new coding agent session through a dedicated chat editor. ## Prerequisites 1. VS Code Insiders 1. **Pre-release GitHub Pull Requests** Extension 1. The following settings: - `"chat.agentSessionsViewLocation": "view"` Ensure that your workspace repository has [Copilot coding agent enabled](https://github.com/settings/copilot/coding_agent) (Microsoft repos have it enabled). Optional: Claude Code installed locally and enabled with [`"github.copilot.chat.advanced.claudeCode.enabled": true`](https://vscodeteam.slack.com/archives/C05BHT75R6G/p1756098722078869) (see [that TPI](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/264419)) ## Steps 1. Open a workspace (like `microsoft/vscode`) where you'd like coding agent to work 1. Open the chat sessions view (sparkle chat icon) 2. Click the `+` next to your coding agent of choice 3. Type a task into the chat window 4. Submit Work will begin on your provided task and its progress streamed to this dedicated chat editor. Copilot coding agent allow you to follow up on a completed chat turn by sending another message. Please validate that this feature works as expected and note any issues. Related TPIs (for context): - https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/264266 - https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/264256 - https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/264384

title: [Bug] [Agent] Copilot Agent Corrupts LaTeX Commands (e.g., \textbf becomes <tab>extbf)
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

### Description
When using the **Copilot Agent** (`@workspace /agent`) to generate or edit LaTeX documents, the Agent critically corrupts LaTeX control sequences by replacing the leading backslash `\` with a Tab character. This renders the generated LaTeX code unusable and non-compilable.

The most common example is the `\textbf{}` command being transformed into `    extbf{}` (where the leading space is actually a Tab character).

### Expected Behavior
The Copilot Agent must preserve the backslash `\` in LaTeX commands. The output should be valid LaTeX code, such as `\textbf{bold text}`.

### Actual Behavior
The Agent replaces the backslash `\` in LaTeX commands with a Tab character, producing output like `    extbf{bold text}` which causes a compilation error in any LaTeX processor.

### Steps to Reproduce
1.  In VS Code, open a workspace containing a LaTeX document (e.g., `document.tex`).
2.  Open the Copilot Chat panel.
3.  Use a command that will trigger the Agent to write LaTeX. For example:
    *   **Command 1 (Direct):** `@workspace /agent Write a LaTeX line that makes the word "Hello" bold using the textbf command.`
    *   **Command 2 (Edit):** Select the word "Hello" in your existing LaTeX document and ask the Agent: `@workspace /agent Make this word bold.`

4.  **Observe the faulty output:** The Agent will suggest code where the backslash is missing and replaced by whitespace.
    *   **Expected Output:** `This is \textbf{bold} text.`
    *   **Actual Output:** `This is     extbf{bold} text.` // This will cause a LaTeX error.




- Copilot Chat Extension Version: Latest
- VS Code Version: Latest
- OS Version: I don't know.
- Feature: agent
- Selected model: Claude 4.0 Sonnet
- Logs: I can't find it.

title: Feature Request: Server-Side Prompt Caching for the Language Model API
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently, the vscode language model API allows extension developers to use language model endpoints registered by the user. This comes with the limitation, that only "user-level" messages are supported.
Also, there is no way to cache the state of the LLM, which increases token usage and response time drastically.

title: Adjust dropdown positioning in settings editor to prevent distance from controls
body:
Fixes #264357

## Problem
Dropdown menus in the settings editor were opening too far away from their trigger controls, causing visual disconnect and poor UX.

## Solution
Added a 10px offset specifically for dropdown positioning in the settings editor by detecting the `.settings-editor` class context.

## Changes
- Modified `getDomNodePagePosition()` in `src/vs/base/browser/dom.ts`
- Added settings page detection using `closest('.settings-editor')` 
- Applied 10px vertical offset only for settings editor dropdowns

## Testing
Verified dropdowns now open with proper proximity to controls in settings editor while maintaining normal behavior elsewhere.

title: Test: background update flow for system setup on windows
body:
Refs: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/249239

- [x] Windows: @rzhao271 (x64)
- [x] Windows: @lszomoru (arm64)

Complexity: 4

Authors: @deepak1556 


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264373%0A%0A&assignees=deepak1556)

---

Same as https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/264372 but for **system setup**. Please test the following scenarios,

**Prerequisite:**

1) Download [build A](https://builds.code.visualstudio.com/builds/insider?commit=08ab85767a1c2a17c818237b60b9ab8c0e22a63e&dev=true)
2) Download [build B](https://builds.code.visualstudio.com/builds/insider?commit=42b483cd88c4caf2c1806219d03071beab0569d8&dev=true)
3) Set `"update.mode": "manual"` and `"update.enableWindowsBackgroundUpdates": true`

**Issue reporting**

When creating issues, please attach the following 3 logs along with the steps to repro

1) Inno updater logs `vscode-inno-updater-*.log` from OS temp directory
2) Inno setup logs `Setup Log *.txt` from OS temp directory
3) Application main process logs, if possible always run with trace level

**Testing:**

_Scenario 1 (Update from A -> B):_

* Install version A following the setup instructions
* Ensure the directory layout of the installed application folder as follows,

```
<version folder> // name matches the first 10 chars of the product commit
bin
app.exe
app.VisualElementsManifest.xml
uninst000.dat
uninst000.exe
```

* Launch version A
* Run `Developer: Apply Update`
* Choose version B setup file
* Once the gear icon changes to signal update is ready to be installed, verify that the directory now has following additional files

```
<version B commit folder>
bin
  | new_app.cmd
new_app.exe
new_app.VisualElementsManifest.xml
```
* Choose restart to update
* Check the about dialog commit points to version B
* Verify that application directory no longer contains `new_` files

_Scenario 2 (Update from A -> B without application restart):_

* Follow the same steps as scenario 1 till the gear icon signals update is ready
* Close the application without choosing restart to update
* Verify that the application directory still ends up performing the background update by renaming `new_` files to current and removed files from old installation
* Verify application doesn't get restarted
* Manually launch the application to verify commit matches version B in the about dialog

_Scenario 3 (Update from A -> B with system restart):_

_If the system doesn't abort the updater process then this scenario is not possible to verify so you can ignore as long as you are in a state where the application folder contains version B otherwise it is a bug_ 

* Follow the same steps as scenario 1 till the gear icon signals update is ready
* Restart the OS system without closing the application
* Verify there is a file `session-ending.flag` under `OS temp dir/vscode-insider-win32-<arch>` folder
* Verify there is a file `updating_version` under the application install folder
* Verify that the application directory hasn't performed any update operations, i-e there are `new_` files present
* Launch the application and confirm it is still version A

NB: In the automatic update flow it will detect pending update on the first update check which happens 30s after application start and reapply the update. Since this is manual update flow that check cannot happen.

**Additional testing:**

1) Ensure cli works fine before and after the update, try to break cli by invoking it in the middle of the update flow
2) Have a tunnel service running and perform the update flow, ensure tunnels get restarted once the update is complete

title: Genericize where tool approvals are handled

labels.name: debt
labels.description: Code quality issues

body:
Currently tool auto-approval happens generically for all tools _except_ the terminal tool which has its own special handling and way of showing the message, including that in `toolSpecificData` rather than the usual `ConfirmedReason`.

I suggest we make auto-approval contributable in the language model data service so that tools that want specific confirmations, like the terminal, can plug into that but still get their data handled in a consistent way.

Steps to Reproduce:

After some time, drag and drop in my wayland system using labwc stops using drag and drop correctly.

For instance trying to drop a clip in a video editor doesn't work.

What happens instead is that vscode intercepts the drop, for some reason.

For some reason vscode is listening to global drops, even if not visible.

The file drop appears in a vscode tab.

This is of course very disrupting.

title: Find in files: allow grouping by glob as well as include/exclude
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

I quite often add exclude globs like `*test*` when I'm looking for "how the thing is actually implemented" rather than how it's tested. But other times I want to know how it's tested, and sometimes I want to know both. I cycle between wanting these things many times a day, so I have to constantly add/delete globs from the "exclude" field.

I'd be happier if there was some kind of an expandable "groups" section, which let me just define as many globs as I wanted and put files matching in collapsible sections.

No extra indexing or search or anything needed, here's an imaginary implementation.

```tsx
<>
  {groupings.map(g => {
    const filteredFiles = foundFiles.filter(f => minimatch(f, g.glob))
    return <>
      <details>
        <summary>Group: {g.glob} (${filteredFiles.length})</summary>
        {filteredFiles.map(f => (
          <Result>{f}</Result> // whatever the current component is
        )}
      </details>
    </>
  })}
</>
```

title: Test: Extensions can register views in secondary sidebar
body:
Refs: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/151681

- [x] anyOS @osortega
- [x] anyOS @hediet

Complexity: 4


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264346%0A%0A&assignees=benibenj)

---

It is now possible for extensions to register view containers in the secondary sidebar (behind the proposed API `contribSecondarySideBar`). To test this use one of our sample extensions which contribute views / view containers. Change the location of an existing view container or create a new view container which contributes to the secondary sidebar like this in `package.json` under `contributes`:

```json
"viewsContainers": {
	"secondarySideBar": [
		{
			"id": "viewContsinerID",
			"title": "View Container Name",
			"icon": "media/dep.svg"
		}
	]
}
```

- Register multiple view containers in the secondary side bar
- Make sure the view containers behave as expected when clicking between them and using the available actions in the context menu (hide & unhide, drag to the primary side bar and reset the location, ...)
- Ensure the chat view is the default view container when opening a new workspace (first in order and the active one)
